misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the computer knows to associate input tokens with the 'names' array or 'scores' array based on the text of the preceding 'System.out.print' prompt, rather than just the sequence of method calls.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's execution model, the Scanner is a sequential token-consumer that is entirely decoupled from the System.out output stream. The computer does not 'wait' for a specific prompt to be satisfied; it simply takes the next available token from the stream in the order the methods are executed. If the user input were provided as name-score pairs (e.g., 'Alice 85 Bob 92'), the student's mental model would fail as the first loop would incorrectly consume '85' as a name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Logic error or Runtime exception (InputMismatchException) if user input format deviates from the strict loop-driven sequence (all names then all scores).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that s.next() will capture a student's full name (e.g., 'Alice Smith') as a single string because it is being stored in a String array element meant for names.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student's mental model fails to account for the notional machine's reliance on whitespace delimiters. Scanner.next() stops reading at the first space, meaning it cannot capture multi-word inputs without being used inside a specific loop or using nextLine(). The computer does not 'know' what constitutes a full name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Logic error (if a student's name contains a space, the second word will be stored as the name of the next student, misaligning the entire parallel array structure).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that 'n-1' will always point to a valid index in the array, assuming that the collection of students will always contain at least one entry.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While the student correctly understands zero-based indexing (using n-1 for the last element), their mental model fails to account for the 'empty state' of the machine. In the Java execution model, an array of size 0 is valid, but accessing index -1 on that array results in a runtime exception.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that s.next() will always capture a single 'name' and stop at the boundary of that entity, regardless of whether the name contains spaces.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student identifies a 'name' as a single unit but the Scanner's next() method operates strictly on whitespace delimiters. If a name like 'Alice Smith' is entered, the mental model of 'one name per index' breaks because the actual Java execution model treats 'Alice' and 'Smith' as two separate tokens.
